div.p: Greetings. I wanted to add these few words hastily, most illustrious man, so that you may understand that Mr. Calvin is still tormented by colic and kidney pains.

How grave and bitter this is to me, I cannot express in words; my sorrow was truly increased when I saw how distressing it was for him that he could not write to you, nor even dictate due to the severity of his illness, and I know how much he values you, as you deserve.
I can hardly write this without tears.
For me, nothing can be more pleasing than when he is able to dictate something that I can convey to you, because I am convinced that you take great delight in his letters.
You, most humane man, forgive your Jonvilliers if he adds this; for I preferred to pour out whatever this is rather than remain silent, oppressed by grief, before you.
I could have, I confess, remained completely silent; but I was compelled by your singular humanity to burst forth into these verses.
Meanwhile, commend him and all of us to God in your prayers and those of your entire church; in turn, we will commend you and the others to the Lord.
Farewell, most excellent man; I pray to God from the heart that He may keep you safe for a long time, guide you with His spirit, and bless your labors.
If our Trecius has already left, I will be surprised that he has not written to me, especially since he has not responded to my last letters.
Geneva, the day before the Nones of June 1563.
Charles de Jonvilliers, your most observant.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, faithful pastor of the Zurich church and most worthy of my respect.
